comments.commentBody: By all accounts she comes across as a lady of great courage and conviction. Quite the role model. A great loss to the nation. Rest in peace, Mrs. Ford.
A good woman!  The Ford's were a real couple with real life foibles and concerns.  They were fundamentally decent people.

Betty Ford was a great first lady for America. As a young activist I recall how having Betty Ford on "our side," supporting ratification of the ERA, reproductive rights, and her openness about her family life. Betty Ford later helped revolutionize our thinking about addiction and treatment for the disease of addiction.

The Ford family was so entertaining and so much like the rest of America. I did not last long in the Republican party after Ford left, realizing this party was headed in the wrong direction. Betty and Gerry Ford were the last moderate Republicans in the White House. She was a wonderful person and I loved her style. She will be missed.

A First Lady of the highest order. After Eleanor Roosevelt, Betty Ford was the most independent First Lady of the 20th century. The friendship and love between Gerald Ford and Betty, evidenced in the hundreds of White House photos, was authentic and also remarkable in the history of presidents and first ladies.

If today's Republican party were to take even 1 page from her life story, the country would be in a better place.  She was First Lady when I was in high school. I loved and admired her then, and I love and now miss her today.  Thanks for the memories.  Prayers to her family, she was a First Lady for the ages.

Thanks to Betty Ford, my life was saved. Having the courage to be open about her addictions in a time when it was especially shameful for women was an impetus for many. I was lucky enough to become a patient at the Betty Ford Center, and have been sober ever since. What a truely great legacy, and I am only one of thousands.

Betty Ford will be long remembered in the Vail area. I met her casually on numerous occasions at public events. But my favorite moment was an exchange a mirth one 4th of July concert in the rain. She & her husband had just spoken from the grandstand and were just returning to their tent, umbrella'd and bookended by the secret service when the couple noticed out tiny group alone on the lawn, coated in large trash bags, baseball caps, sipping champagne from plastic flutes, ignoring the downpour, but happily enjoying the symphony. We rose to honor their passing. Betty Ford took in our bedraggled appearance and joy in the day, and her eyes twinkled, and then her smile broke out full sail. She nodded, just enough to let us know she almost wished she was in our group before moving on. Later the Secret Service brought us a complimentary bottle of bubbly. We joke that she thought my service dog was cute!
And a correction to this obit. The Fords had a home in Beaver Creek Resort, not Vail. By the standards of the resort it was modest, not elaborate.

She lives on the language of my heart and in the sunshine of the spirit.
Thank you Betty Ford - one of the greatest women of our time. R.I.P.

Betty Ford, courageous Path finder: Artist/Dancer. Breast Cancer Survivor - who was among (IF NOT) the FIRST WOMEN to put a FACE on this Disease. ADDICTION SURVIVOR: Who went out of her way to de-stigmatize Addiction.
How many people world wide have benefited from her example in beating substance addictions? How many lives and families saved?
WHAT A WOMAN! NOT just words, but examples. Not just hyperbole, but Action.
And, thanks, to her amazingly courageous candid-ness, we are so far advanced worldwide in understanding chemical addictions as something we can openly discuss and moreover understand as neurological conditions that can be treated humanely as the neurological diseases that they so often are. If not for Betty Ford, this might never have happened - and hundreds if not thousands might still be suffering out of view.

To her Family: You have so much to be Proud of. RIP Mrs. Ford, you have left this world a better place.
What Republican woman TODAY would have the courage to stand behind Betty's stalwart principles of human rights for Women?
I can think of NONE. Women of all stripes will do well to study Mrs. Ford's life and the underpinnings of her political/philosophical views.
Betty Ford, RIP and THANK YOU. Your gifts to humankind will be felt forever.

Ah, History. If only, if only, we would actually pay attention. 100% of this story has happened before; all the, greed, lust for glory, pain, anguish, fear, death, and drama.

Sinclair Lewis wrote a book about it. A novelized report, but taken from life: "Arrowsmith". His father was a doctor, and he saw it all first hand.

I looked for any mention of that- in the article, and the comments. In vain. What fools we mortals be.

Sometime about now, even the businessmen out there ought to start figuring out- the people pushing "new genomic science", the same folks pushing genetic engineering- are kids playing with tinkertoys they do not understand. They are vastly impressed with themselves and what they think they know- but their predictions fail- like clockwork. Time to listen perhaps to their critics- who've been saying for years, "It's a lot more complex than that."

I love the Marpac Sound Screen.  I bought my first one in 1969.  It lasted about 30 years.  My second one is about 12 years old now and the sound is very soothing to me.  I even take it on vacations.  It's one of the most dependable electric devices I've ever owned.  I see some postings for white noise generated by using in between stations on FM radio.  Anyone that can do that, my hat is off to you.  I not only couldn't sleep to that sound - I couldn't stand to be in the same room with that sound.

God bless Betty Ford.

Her courage and honesty about her own substance abuse problems inspired millions of Americans from 'both sides of the aisle' to find the help and support they need in hundreds of programs likewise inspired by Mrs. Ford's leadership.

The Dali Lama himself has done no more than Betty Ford.
Rest in Peace. You were a strong and classy lady.
Thank you, Betty Ford!

I was just a kid when Betty Ford was First Lady but I remember her being so open about her breast cancer surgery and her support of the ERA.  In hindsight I realize that those revelations, along with her subsequent candor about her addictions, led many Americans like me to feel much more comfortable with discussing "personal issues" in the public domain. For prior generations, these kinds of "imperfections" were often covered up, even among extended family.  The true impact on our society of Betty Ford's willingness to be open and candid may be impossible to measure.

Rest in peace Betty.  She was the first First Lady (at least in my lifetime) who eschewed the plastic persona of her "role" and in doing so, became a genuine role model for people struggling with a myriad of issues ... omigosh, with life: substance abuse, depression and breast cancer.  Above all, she was a survivor.  God bless her.

Never, by any means, a Republican, I always admired Betty, and for that matter her, somewhat overshadowed, husband. And it was always the simple idea that she clearly thought her own thoughts, expressed her own opinions, and seemed to always, at least try, to keep her mind open. I wonder what she thought of another Republican woman, Michele Bachmann, and her callous signature of "The Marriage Vow", a rambling and horrifyingly ignorant and fearful tract, about nothing but the natural supremacy of white, Christian, heterosexual, family conjoined Americans. I'll take, for my respected adversary, the party of Betty. But it's gone. So I don't want to hear any eulogies from that part of the room, thank you.

Betty Ford was a beautiful, engaging, and inspirational model for young women in the 1970s and 1980s:  she almost invented self-help by her own brave example.  For her children, my deepest condolences.

Oh no!  Even as a dyed-in-the-wool, lifelong leftie liberal, I am saddened to see that Betty Ford has departed us.  I admired her courage and feistiness immensely.  She made America a better place and I wish there were more like her.  My thanks to her family for sharing her with us for so many years.

Betty Ford had nothing to feel inferior about; she was a spectacular First Lady who brightened the hearts of the nation following the previous Presidential disaster.  In my opinion, her star shone brighter than her husband's, and she inspired many more people by her independent spirit and courage.  She was a true American hero.

Her husband became the President of the United States by sheer chance having never even contested for the Office. Yet, Betty and he held the post with grace and brought back to the White House the dignity it had lost.

She was the first woman to bring feminist ideals into the mainstream, and quite naturally, not as an ideologue. Her massive influence in the areas you have mentioned perhaps cannot be grasped by those who are now young.

Total class. It was indeed a Grand Old Party.

Godspeed, Elizabeth.

"Alcoholism was declared a disease by the American Medical Association and the American Psychiatric Association in 1955.

But awareness of that concept grew slowly.

People didn't stop laughing at drunk acts like Dean Martin and Foster Brooks until after Betty Ford opened her chemical dependency treatment center in Rancho Mirage in 1982.

Ford helped create a new sobering reality for America by lending her name, energy and experience as a recovering addict to the center."

Thank you for a great contribution Mrs. Ford.

I see at least three major orthopedic syndromes being "born." Not to mention one major COA (cause of accident) epidemic ready to sweep the country.

Ah! From drive-in movie screen to theater screen to TVs then back up to desktop computer, down to laptop, way up to big screen TV, now zapped back down to cell phone postage stamp images.

Wonder what that does to the visual cortex over a life time. (?)
All Size Screen Syndrome. We got an new acronym too.

Ambulance air horns. Unmuffled motorcycles. Garbage trucks slamming down commercial size bins. Screaming drunks and arguing addicts. I hear it all living in downtown San Francisco. I have tried many different solutions to achieve artificially induced silence.

The best approach I have found to date and also an inexpensive solution is a foam plus a silicon ear plug.

I first insert a foam earplug then cap it off by molding a silicon earplug over the top.

This whole is truly quieter than the sum of its parts.
